ul.li1: 1The words of Lemuel, the king—an oracle
ul.li2: that his mother taught him:
ul.li1: 2What, my son? And what, my son in my womb?
ul.li2: And what, son of my vows?
ul.li1: 3Do not give your strength to the women,
ul.li2: and your ways to destroy kings.
ul.li1: 4It is not for the kings, O Lemuel;
ul.li2: drinking wine is not for the kings,
nor is strong drink for rulers.
ul.li1: 5Or else he will drink and forget what has been decreed,
ul.li2: and he will pervert the rightsHebrew “right” of all the afflicted.Literally “sons of affliction”
ul.li1: 6Give strong drink to him who is perishing,
ul.li2: and wine to those in bitter distress.Literally “to bitterness of soul”
ul.li1: 7He will drink and forget his poverty,
ul.li2: and his misery he will not remember any more.
ul.li1: 8Open your mouth for the mute,
ul.li2: for the rightsHebrew “right” of all the needy.Literally “the sons of the needy”
ul.li1: 9Open your mouth, judge righteousness,
ul.li2: and defend the poor and needy.

chapter.pericope: An Excellent WomanProv 31:10–31 is an acrostic poem

ul.li1: 10A womanOr “wife” of excellence,Or “strength,” or “valor,” or “ability,” or “efficiency” who will find?
ul.li2: For her worth is far more than precious jewels.
ul.li1: 11The heart of her husbandOr “lord” trusts in her,
ul.li2: and gain he will not lack.
ul.li1: 12She does him good, but not harm
ul.li2: all the days of her life.
ul.li1: 13She seeks wool and flax,
ul.li2: and she works with the diligence of her hands.Literally “her palms”
ul.li1: 14She is like the ships of a merchant;
ul.li2: from far off she brings her food;Or “bread”
ul.li1: 15And she arises while it is still night,
ul.li2: and gives food to her household,
and tasks to her servant girls.
ul.li1: 16She considers a field and buys it,
ul.li2: from the fruit of her handLiterally “her palm” she plants a vineyard.
ul.li1: 17She girds her waist in strength,
ul.li2: and makes her arms strong.
ul.li1: 18She perceives that her merchandise is good;
ul.li2: her lamp does not go out in the night.
ul.li1: 19Her hands she puts onto the distaff,A stick or spindle onto which wool or flax is wound in preparation for spinning
ul.li2: and her palms hold a spindle.
ul.li1: 20Her palm she opens to the poor,
ul.li2: and her hand she reaches out to the needy.
ul.li1: 21She does not fear for her house when it snows,
ul.li2: for her entire householdLiterally “all her house, household” is clothed in crimson.
ul.li1: 22She makes for herself coverings;
ul.li2: her clothing is fine linen and purple.
ul.li1: 23Her husbandOr “lord” is known at the gates,
ul.li2: in his seat among the elders of the land.
ul.li1: 24Linen garments she makes and sells,
ul.li2: and she supplies sashes for the merchants.
ul.li1: 25Strength and dignity are her clothing,
ul.li2: and she laughs at the future.Literally “to the day/time coming after”
ul.li1: 26She opens her mouth with wisdom,
ul.li2: and instruction of kindness is upon her tongue.
ul.li1: 27She looks after the ways of her household,
ul.li2: and the bread of idleness she will not eat.
ul.li1: 28Her children rise and consider her happy,
ul.li2: her husbandOr “lord” also, and he praises her;
ul.li1: 29“Many daughters have done excellence,Or “strength,” or “valor,” or “ability,” or “efficiency”
ul.li2: but you surpassLiterally “you ascend over” all of them.”
ul.li1: 30CharmHebrew “The charm” is deceit and beautyHebrew “the beauty” is vain;Or “vapor,” or “emptiness,” or “breath”
ul.li2: but a woman who fears Yahweh shall be praised.
ul.li1: 31Give to her from the fruit of her hand,
ul.li2: and may they praise her works in the city gates.
